716969f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Morris Street and viewing towards Trinity Church.  At the right is a portion of the Standard Oil Building.  Under construction, to the left is the Aldrich Court Building.  Compare this view with an almost identical one, (the of latter date) in King's Handbook of New York (1893), page 143.

1882

M. Gray
Thru New York Historical Society

716939f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Morris Street, showing the beginning of this important thoroughfare. In the center, preceding "Steamship Row" is New York's first park, Bowling Green. Surrounding same are, the Welles Building, the Produce Exchange, the first Washington Building and the Bowling Green Building. Note the Broadway street
cars and their electrified track.
About 1890-5
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716970f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Morris Street, as photographed from the Bowling Green Building (No. 5-11 Broadway). At the left and right respectively are the Columbia and the Standard Oil Buildings. Thru the center appears the 21-story Manhattan Life Building, and the 21-story American Surity Company Building. To the left is the spire atop Trinity Church.
About 1893
Ewing Galloway

716974f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Morris Street (left) as seen from
No. 1 Broadway. Note the cable cars.
1896.
Brown Brothers.

716958f-a.text:
Broadway, adjoining and south of the S. W. corner of Morris Street (right not included), showing the site of the 22 story Cunard Building prior to improvement. At the left margin appears a portion ot the adjoining Bowling Green Building.
About 1910
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716977f-a.text:
Broadway, north from and including Morris Street, showing mainly the west side of the Street.
1917.
Edwin Levick

716957f-a.text:
Broadway, West side, south from Morris Street (right) to Battery Place (left), showing 3 structures occupying this front; The Cunard, The Bowling Green and the Washington Bldg. The first of these is the highest and appears prominently, occupying as it does nearly half of the entire block bounded by the aforementioned points and Greenwich Street, its westerly side. The photographer is atop No. 50 Broadway (opposite side) and is viewing southwestward to show in addition a glimpse of Battery Park and the apparently taller Whitehall Bldg. on West Street.
About 1925.
Albert Rothschild

716975f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Morris Street, showing W.P.A. employees removing street car rails as a portion of a City Wide project. For data pertinent to this subject -- see -- New York Times, October 21, 1937 page 25.
August 25, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

716978f.text:
Broadway, nos. 32-56, Manhattan.
The arrow indicates the Tower Building, built 1888-9 and razed 1914, which was the "earliest example of skeleton frame construction ever erected." (Stokes, Iconography of Manhattan Island v.3 p. 841)

716981f.text:
Harriman 39 Broadway Bldg. just completed, and to be
formally opened May 1.
1928
N.Y. Public Library
Astor, Lenox
Tilden Foundation
Neg #2308

716982f-a.text:
41 to 55 Broadway, west side, north from a point north of Morris Street to Exchange Alley (right), showing prominently the lower floors of No. 41-45 that were occupied by the N.R.A. headquarters. On the extreme right appears a portion of the 32-story Adams Building No. 57-61 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of the afore mentioned Alley.
November 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
